SHARK PATTERN ANALYIS BY ATA  
**EURUSD Weekly Analysis**  
  
The weekly chart is currently slowing PA down because we are at the potential C leg of a Shark Pattern. (Additionally if you look left to past candles you will see what was support earlier becomes resistance now).  
  
The current weekly candle actually pierced a little higher through that level **1.0873** but did not close above it yet which leaves the Shark pattern still in play.  
  
Another nearby pattern is the AB=CD pattern waiting at 1.0984 but since there are 100 pips inbetween I prefer to rely on the shark pattern and look for sell opportunities on smaller timeframes.  
  
I am looking for sell opportunities with tight SL and if 1.09-1.0915 zone breaks then bulls might have a final run limited with 100-120 pips.  
  
My conclusion is that somewhere inside these 100-120 pips the paused weekly bearish trend will continue to complete any of these patterns. Especially the shark pattern can push price at least down to D point: 1.0236 and even lower to its maximum range to D-max: 0.998  
  
Stay Green

**Take note of individual days of the week. This is usually how a week goes:**  
**Monday â€“ investors get back to work and perform initial analysis (possible low dynamics).**  
**Tuesday â€“ an exchange of information between banks and investors gets underway, movement becomes more dynamic.**  
**Wednesday â€“ the market has settled for a direction and follows it.**  
**Thursday â€“ movement reaches its maximum level, everyone attempts to join it.**  
**Friday â€“ profit realization and partial position closure before the weekend (possible sudden and unpredictable movements).**

When the indicator is dragged onto a chart it sets the levels based on the high low for that Symbol of course if you drag another Symbol/chart onto that existing chart then the price range is going to be completely different, for example set the indicator up on the EURUSD chart and lets say for the sake of simplicity the high= 1.18000 and the Low = 1.17000 then drag the GBPUSD chart onto the EUR chart changing it to a GBPUSD chart, compress the chart and you will see the indicator set to the 1.18000/1.17000 levels on the GBPUSD chart. This is the problem when people do not give all the information when requesting an indicator, at no point did you ever explain how you were attempting to use this indicator so your method of use was never considered when the indicator was coded. When a coder asks for ALL the INFORMATION they mean ALL! This may come as a surprise but I cannot read your mind!!!![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f914.png?v=15.1)  
The only way around it with this indicator is to save it as a **set file** and load that set file for each different chart.

Hi classy,  
As I have said previously I encourage you to ask questions, this latest problem has made me think ![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f914.png?v=15.1) and I have coded a script which you can use to reset the indicator for each new chart, the only issue is that the script will delete any other trend lines on the chart but has the advantage that it will work if several  
Numbered Candle Breakout indicators are loaded on the same chart regardless of the different magic numbers.  
You can either drag the script out of the navigator window onto the new chart or setup a hot key ( I think a hot key is quickest ) and the script will reset the indicator onto the new chart with the previous indicator settings intact. To setup a hot key **right click the script** in the list and select **Set hotkey** then choose the control of **ctrl or alt** and then choose the key which is **any letter** off your keyboard.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  

Attached File(s)

![File Type: ex4](https://assets.faireconomy.media/images/attach/ex4.gif) [NCB script.ex4](/attachment/file/2922873?d=1533117667) 23 KB | 300 downloads 

  
  
This script works **without deleting trend lines** but will only work if the indicator is loaded on the chart with the**default magic number "12345"** but this is probably the best option if only one Numbered Candle Breakout indicator is used and loaded on a chart.![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)![](https://resources.faireconomy.media/images/emojis/64/1f60a.png?v=15.1)  
  

Attached File(s)

![File Type: ex4](https://assets.faireconomy.media/images/attach/ex4.gif) [NCB magic script.ex4](/attachment/file/2922988?d=1533122306) 23 KB | 338 downloads 

  
  
Please note these scripts are to refresh the Numbered Candle Breakout indicator so it resets to the new pair price levels when a new pair chart is dragged onto an existing chart from the navigator window.

Eur Aud Top-Down PTZ. some friends asked me to describe how i analyze my ptz. let's get started.  
Let's start with month ptz. we can a line which is our main focus .now we will try to more clear ptz  
in weekly ptz we can see some buy pressure in current candle /price(we always focus on current price/ptz/smart money's movement)  
For clear ptz we can zoom in/out our chart.  
In Daily PTz we used Fibonacci here .some time use equidistance channel ED /harmonic pattern/can/chart pattern /fibo fan(i mean wee need to confirm, to go buy or sell evidence) can see more clearly our buy ptz or sell ptz to take our trading decision. Now we know we should go for short.  
we can check 4h/1h ptz for our set up/ptz too .If you have any questions, please let me know. Share your views too.  
This my top-down process.we can follow this step to analyze any pair/index/metal any time frame.

Hi Classy  
  
This guy offers some good advice about the way people make mistakes like holding trades etc but imo he makes a dumbass comment about pessimism and optimism.  
  
"Become optimistic about winning trades, let them run and become pessimistic about losing trades". In my book this comment has 2 flaws.  
  
1\. Using this philosophy in trading is reinforcing the Fear and Greed monster to surface. Letting trades run because you are optimistic they are winning is just bad form and you will likely see your profits wither away when the market corrects. Pessimism for losing trades will encourage you to cut short trades that could follow your plan to return to a winning status.  
  
2\. Encouraging any sort of emotional response imo is detrimental to a good trader. A losing trade and a winning trade are just two numbers that encompass the whole within your trading plan.  
  
I liked the video above this one however.  
  
Thanks for the postings.   
Matt.
